clusters.title: Teen dies after electric dirt bike crash on the Gold Coast
clusters.neutral_headline: Teenager Dies in Electric Dirt Bike Crash
bullet_summary: Police said the 15-year-old rider hit a raised pedestrian walkway before striking two poles, the impact throwing him 10 metres
Reported by 9News, The Age, ABC News Australia

items.title: Teen dies after electric dirt bike crash on the Gold Coast
items.standfirst: Police said the 15-year-old rider hit a raised pedestrian walkway before striking two poles, the impact throwing him 10 metres.
items.content: A teenager has died after an e-bike crash on the Gold Coast this morning.The 15-year-old boy from Worongary was riding an electric dirt bike along Broadbeach Boulevard in Broadbeach about 3am when he lost control outside the local surf lifesaving club.Police said he hit a raised pedestrian walkway before striking two poles, the impact throwing him 10 metres.READ MORE: Man's new Tesla struck by suspected meteorite on remote Aussie highway He died at the scene. Friends laid flowers at the site as police issued an urgent warning."This particular bike, though, is being sold as an e-trail bike. They can sell for over $10,000," Kylie Rigg from Queensland Police said."They can travel over 60 kilometres an hour, they are not bicycles."[Teens] do not have the skill level, they do not have the protective clothing to ride them."Investigators are probing if the rider was going too fast and police are appealing for witnesses. It's the state's second e-bike fatality this week after eight year-old Zeke Hondow was killed on the Sunshine Coast. There have been calls for a crackdown on e-bikes in the state.Legal e-bikes can be ridden on paths unless otherwise signed, as long as riders obey bicycle rules such as wearing a helmet.They must have a maximum continuous power output of 250 watts and be pedal-powered with motor assistance up to 25km/h.There are no age limits for riding e-bikes in Queensland. Bike motors with more than 250 watts are illegal, as are throttle-powered bikes without pedals, which are technically electric motorcycles and require registration, insurance and a licence and cannot be ridden on paths.DOWNLOAD THE 9NEWS APP: Stay across all the latest in breaking news, sport, politics and the weather via our news app and get notifications sent straight to your smartphone. Available on the Apple App Store and Google Play.

clusters.title: 'Morons': Liam Gallagher blasts fan after first Oasis gig in Melbourne
clusters.neutral_headline: Liam Gallagher Reacts to Flare at Oasis Concert
bullet_summary: A flare let off by a crowd member at the first of three Melbourne Oasis concerts at Docklands Stadium on Friday night angers the band's co-founder Liam Gallagher, sparking an expletive-laden post
Reported by 9News, The Age, ABC News Australia

items.title: 'Morons': Liam Gallagher blasts fan after first Oasis gig in Melbourne
items.standfirst: O asis singer Liam Gallagher has called out a fan who threw flares at the British band's first concert in Australia.
items.content: O asis singer Liam Gallagher has called out a fan who threw flares at the British band's first concert in Australia.The flare was thrown into the crowd at Marvel Stadium during hit song Champagne Supernova, with Liam saying "that's naughty, naughty, naughty," according to fans. Footage posted on social media shows flames erupting into the crowd. READ MORE: Calls for Andrew to face questions in the UK and US after being stripped of titles Gallagher later said on X " To the massive c--- who launched that flare into the crowd last night at the gig in Melbourne you are one seriopusly f----- up individual and you will get yours trust me."Fans on Reddit called it a "scumbag" act and called the people "morons"."Hope everyone was okay where it landed and no one got badly burnt," one fan said."They could have burnt some poor girls face. Hope they get arrested and banned from gigs," another said.In 2019 a fan at an Oasis concert in Sheffield in the UK was burned by a flare. Stacey Andrew told the BBC the flare fell down her top and set fire to her shirt and she feared she would be "scarred for life."Victoria Police said the incident has not been reported to them and there were no arrests.READ MORE: Trips to the doctor just got cheaper thanks to $7.9 billion overhaul Marvel Stadium told 9News no one was harmed, adding: "We'll leave the on record comments to Liam Gallagher's post." Earlier this year there were calls for extra security after a teenage boy was allegedly caught trying to smuggle weapons into Marvel Stadium during the Swans-Bombers AFL clash.Oasis has five shows across Melbourne and Sydney.The band will play two more shows in the Victorian capital tonight and on Tuesday. Oasis will then fly to Sydney for two shows at Accor Stadium, on Friday and next Saturday.

clusters.title: Woman charged with murder of Perth baby
clusters.neutral_headline: Woman Charged with Murder of Perth Baby
bullet_summary: A 28-year-old woman has been charged with murder after an eight-month-old baby was found dead in a home in Perth’s south
The eight-month-old's body was found by police and paramedics at a home about 40km south of Perth with what's believed to be stab wounds

items.title: Woman charged with murder of Perth baby
items.standfirst: A 28-year-old woman has been charged with murder after an eight-month-old baby was found dead in a home in Perth’s south.
items.content: A 28-year-old woman has been charged with murder after an eight-month-old baby was found dead in a home in Perth’s south.

items.title: Woman charged with murder over death of baby near Perth
items.standfirst: The eight-month-old's body was found by police and paramedics at a home about 40km south of Perth with what's believed to be stab wounds.
items.content: A 28-year-old woman has been charged with murder after the death of a baby south of Perth.Emergency services found the eight-month-old dead at a home in Baldivis about 10.15am yesterday after neighbours reported hearing a woman screaming out the front of the property.Detectives deemed the death suspicious and began questioning a woman, believed to be the baby's mother.READ MORE: Searchers draining dam today in renewed search for missing boy GusThe 28-year-old, Alanah Gail Smithwick, was taken to Fiona Stanley Hospital in a stable condition and has since been charged with murder."My heart literally just dropped, we never ever thought that that would happen - they always seemed like such a happy family, just out the front playing," neighbour Jessica Randall said.Forensic officers and detectives continued gathering evidence for a second day as they try to piece together the circumstances of the tragic incident.Police and paramedics arrived to the Winpara Way home just after 10am yesterday morning, finding the tiny body with what is believed to have been stab wounds.A witness told 9News a woman, who identified as the baby's grandmother, attended the scene shortly after police arrived and removed a toddler from the home.Smithwick was due to face the Rockingham Magistrates Court today, but her appearance was postponed as she remained in hospital.She will face court at an undetermined later date.DOWNLOAD THE 9NEWS APP: Stay across all the latest in breaking news, sport, politics and the weather via our news app and get notifications sent straight to your smartphone. Available on the Apple App Store and Google Play.

The charge relates to an eight-month-old baby.

clusters.title: Rock climber's dramatic rescue after getting tangled in ropes
clusters.neutral_headline: Rock Climber Rescued After Getting Tangled

items.title: Rock climber's dramatic rescue after getting tangled in ropes
items.standfirst: Emergency services were called to the Onkaparinga River National Park around 12.30pm when a man became tangled in his climbing ropes around 10 metres from the ground.
items.content: A rock climber is tonight in a serious condition at Flinders Medical Centre following a dramatic rescue at Clarendon in the Adelaide Hills.Emergency services were called to the Onkaparinga River National Park around 12.30pm when a man became tangled in his climbing ropes around 10 metres from the ground.The rescue helicopter arrived at the scene as police, paramedics and fire crews made their way in on the ground.READ MORE: Child, 7, ran to get help after Hunter Valley mum killed in alleged DV attackIt's understood the climber - aged in his 70s - was so badly tangled he had to be winched out by the helicopter.It was around two hours later the man was finally flown out to safety.He touched down at Flinders around 3pm and was wheeled inside for treatment.He remains in a serious but stable condition.DOWNLOAD THE 9NEWS APP: Stay across all the latest in breaking news, sport, politics and the weather via our news app and get notifications sent straight to your smartphone. Available on the Apple App Store and Google Play.

clusters.title: Large hail and lightning hit Queensland as residents brace for severe storms
clusters.neutral_headline: Severe Storms Bring Hail and Lightning to Queensland

items.title: Large hail and lightning hit Queensland as residents brace for severe storms
items.standfirst: A dangerous 'super cell' storm threatening Australia's east coast has struck southeastern Queensland bringing large hail, lightning and cutting power to hundreds.
items.content: A dangerous 'super cell' storm threatening Australia's east coast has struck southeastern Queensland bringing large hail, lightning and cutting power to hundreds.

items.title: Power cut to hundreds as severe storm pummels Queensland
items.standfirst: A dangerous 'super cell' storm has struck southeastern Queensland bringing large hail, lightning and cutting power to hundreds.
items.content: Hail, thunder and lightning has hit south eastern Queenslandcutting power to hundreds.Authorities are warning residents in northern NSW, the Gold Coast, Brisbane and the Sunshine Coast to stay inside tonight, as the 'super cell' thunderstorms move across the area.The storm struck Queensland's Southern and Darling Down region around lunchtime, bringing hailstones as large as nine centimetres.READ MORE: Man's new Tesla struck by suspected meteorite on remote Aussie highwayFive to eight centimetre hail fell across Toowoomba, Gatton, the Sunshine Coast, the Lockyer Valley and Brisbane as heavy rain continued to drench the region.Lightning and dark clouds rolled in over Brisbane about 3pm, where the power was cut to almost 700 residents in Bowen Hills.There are even warnings of tornadoes. "When it comes to the wind, there is even an outside chance that we could see a tornado or two touch down with the most intense, most severe thunderstorm cells later on today," BoM meteorologist Angus Hines said.Severe thunderstorm warnings remain in place , with the Bureau cautioning the possibility of heavy rainfall that could lead to flash flooding, possibly giant hailstones and destructive winds across northern NSW and much of Queensland.The worst of the storm is expected to hit Surfers Paradise, Gold Coast, the Brisbane metro area, the Sunshine Coast, Maleny and Noosa Heads.The Burnett region, Kingaroy and Gympie, as well as Biloela and Toowoomba are also in the firing line, Bureau of Meteorology meteorologist Angus Hines said. "When it comes to the wind, there is even an outside chance that we could see a tornado or two touch down with the most intense, most severe thunderstorm cells later on today,"Hines said.Residents in the NSW Northern Tablelands and across the North West Slopes and Plains, including Tamworth and Moree are also expected to be hit by the storms.READ MORE: 'Taken in a minute': Tributes for woman killed in freak lightning strikeCoastal areas such as Port Macquarie, Coffs Harbour, Grafton, Ballina, Lismore and Byron Bay are also in the firing line. Residents have been advised to pack away or secure outdoor furniture, toys and trampolines, park cars away from trees, close doors and windows.The Bureau urged locals across northern NSW and south eastern Queensland to remain inside a "strong building" until the storm passes and advised against driving.The state has been hit with severe thunderstorm weather for almost a week.However, authorities have urged locals to keep up to date with the Bureau of Meteorology weather warnings due to how quickly the weather can turn.Rainy conditions and storms in some areas may continue tomorrow, but overall conditions are expected to improve.Inland areas from Brisbane to Bundaberg may still see severe thunderstorms tomorrow. DOWNLOAD THE 9NEWS APP: Stay across all the latest in breaking news, sport, politics and the weather via our news app and get notifications sent straight to your smartphone. Available on the Apple App Store and Google Play.

ai_summary: Southeastern Queensland experienced a dangerous "super cell" storm.
